Paris: The Eiffel Tower was originally intended to be dismantled after 20 years
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city
The Louvre is the world's most visited museum
Berlin: Berlin has more bridges than Venice - over 1,700
The city is 9 times larger than Paris
Berlin's first traffic light was installed in 1924
Madrid: Madrid is Europe's highest capital at 667m above sea level
The city has more bars per capita than any other EU capital
Madrid's Retiro Park was once exclusive to royalty
Rome: Rome has a museum dedicated entirely to pasta
The city has more than 2,000 fountains
Cats in Rome are protected by law
Lisbon: Lisbon is older than Rome by 4 centuries
The city has the longest bridge in Europe (17km)
Lisbon's tram 28 has been running since 1914
Warsaw: Warsaw's Old Town was completely rebuilt after WWII
The city has a mermaid as its symbol
Warsaw has Europe's narrowest house at just 152cm wide
Amsterdam: There are more bicycles than people in the city
Brussels: Brussels produces over 220,000 tonnes of chocolate per year
The Manneken Pis statue has over 1,000 costumes
Brussels has the world's largest number of comic murals
Vienna: Vienna is home to the world's oldest zoo (1752)
Mozart, Beethoven, and Freud all lived in Vienna
Bern: Bern's Old City is a UNESCO World Heritage Site
Einstein developed his Theory of Relativity in Bern
The city is named after bears, its heraldic animal
Stockholm: The city hosts the Nobel Prize ceremony every year
Stockholm's metro is called the world's longest art gallery
Oslo: Oslo awards the Nobel Peace Prize annually
The city is surrounded by forests and fjords
Oslo's opera house roof is walkable by visitors
Copenhagen: Copenhagen's Tivoli Gardens inspired Walt Disney
The Little Mermaid statue is only 4 feet tall
Copenhagen aims to be carbon neutral by 2025
Helsinki: Helsinki has more than 300 islands in its archipelago
The city hosted the 1952 Summer Olympics
Athens: Athens is one of the oldest cities, with a 3,400-year history
Democracy was invented in Athens around 500 BC
The Parthenon has no straight lines in its design
Prague: Prague Castle is the largest ancient castle complex in the world
The Astronomical Clock has been running since 1410
Prague has been called 'the city of a hundred spires'
Budapest: Budapest was originally two cities: Buda and Pest
The city has the largest thermal water cave system in the world
Bucharest: Bucharest's Palace of Parliament is the world's heaviest building
The city was once called 'Little Paris'
Bucharest has one of Europe's oldest electric tram networks
Sofia: Sofia is one of Europe's oldest cities, dating back 7,000 years
The city sits at the foot of Vitosha Mountain
Sofia has free mineral water fountains throughout the city
Zagreb: Zagreb's upper town has gas-lit lanterns still lit by hand daily
The city has the shortest funicular railway in the world
Zagreb's cathedral twin spires are the tallest buildings in Croatia
Ljubljana: Ljubljana has a dragon as its symbol and mascot
The city was European Green Capital in 2016
Ljubljana's car-free city center is one of Europe's largest
Bratislava: Bratislava is the only capital bordering two countries
The city's Old Town has hidden underground passages
Dublin: Dublin's Phoenix Park is twice the size of Central Park
The Guinness brewery has a 9,000-year lease
Dublin is home to Europe's oldest pub (900 AD)
Belgrade: Belgrade's fortress has been destroyed and rebuilt 40 times
The city sits at the confluence of the Danube and Sava rivers
Belgrade has one of the world's largest Orthodox churches
Kyiv: Kyiv's metro system has some of the deepest stations in the world
The city has over 1,000 years of recorded history
Kyiv's Motherland Monument is taller than the Statue of Liberty
Tallinn: Tallinn's Old Town is one of Europe's best-preserved medieval cities
The city has free public transport for residents
Riga: Riga has the largest collection of Art Nouveau buildings in Europe
The city's Christmas tree tradition started in 1510
Riga's Central Market is housed in former Zeppelin hangars
Vilnius: Vilnius has declared itself an independent republic (Užupis)
The city has one of Europe's largest Old Towns
Vilnius University is one of the oldest in Eastern Europe (1579)
Tirana: Tirana's colorful buildings were painted to brighten the city
The city has a pyramid that was once a museum for Enver Hoxha
Tirana has transformed from grey communist city to vibrant capital
Skopje: Skopje was 80% destroyed by an earthquake in 1963
Mother Teresa was born in Skopje
The city has more statues per capita than most capitals
Podgorica: Podgorica has over 250 sunny days per year
The city was known as Titograd from 1946-1992
Podgorica sits at the meeting of five rivers
Sarajevo: The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand started WWI here
Sarajevo has a tunnel used to survive a 4-year siege
Chișinău: Chișinău is known for its Soviet-era architecture
The city's wine cellars are among the world's largest
Chișinău was almost completely destroyed in WWII
Minsk: Minsk was rebuilt from scratch after WWII
The city has one of the longest main avenues in Europe
Minsk's library is shaped like a giant diamond
Reykjavík: Reykjavík is the world's northernmost capital
The city is heated entirely by geothermal energy
Luxembourg City: Luxembourg City has UNESCO-listed fortress remains
The city has more Michelin stars per capita than any other
Luxembourg is one of three official EU capitals
Valletta: Valletta is the smallest EU capital by population
The entire city is a UNESCO World Heritage Site
Valletta was built by the Knights of St. John in the 1500s
Nicosia: Nicosia is the world's last divided capital city
The city has been continuously inhabited for 4,500 years
Nicosia has ancient Venetian walls still surrounding the old city
Monaco: Monaco is the second smallest country in the world
The Monaco Grand Prix runs through city streets
Monaco has more millionaires per capita than any country
Andorra la Vella: Andorra la Vella is Europe's highest capital at 1,023m
The city has no airport or train station
Andorra has not been at war for over 1,000 years
London: London has over 170 museums, many of which are free
Big Ben is actually the name of the bell, not the tower
London's Underground is the oldest metro system in the world
Moscow: Moscow's metro stations are like underground palaces
Red Square is named for 'beautiful', not the color
Moscow has the most billionaires of any city in Europe
Vaduz: Vaduz Castle is home to the only reigning prince in Europe
Liechtenstein has no airport and no army
Vaduz is one of the smallest capitals in the world
San Marino: San Marino claims to be the world's oldest republic
The entire country is a UNESCO World Heritage Site
San Marino has more cars than people
Pristina: Pristina has one of the youngest populations in Europe
The city has a statue of Bill Clinton
Pristina's Newborn monument changes design each independence day
